rev.diff:
Line 37: Line 37:
Google's declared [[code of conduct]] is "[[Don't Be Evil]]", a phrase which they went so far as to include in their [[prospectus]] (AKA "red herring" or "S-1") for their [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]], noting "We believe strongly that in the long term, we will be better served — as shareholders and in all other ways — by a company that does good things for the world even if we forgo some short term gains." That this statement was in their initial filing is important from a corporate perspective. Were it not, they would be obligated to sacrifice this ideal in order to maintain shareholder value where the two came into conflict.
Google's declared [[code of conduct]] is "[[Don't Be Evil]]", a phrase which they went so far as to include in their [[prospectus]] (AKA "red herring" or "S-1") for their [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]], noting "We believe strongly that in the long term, we will be better served — as shareholders and in all other ways — by a company that does good things for the world even if we forgo some short term gains." That this statement was in their initial filing is important from a corporate perspective. Were it not, they would be obligated to sacrifice this ideal in order to maintain shareholder value where the two came into conflict.

Their site includes humorous features such as cartoon modifications [http://www.google.com/holidaylogos.html] of their logo for special occasions, the option to display the site in fictional or humorous languages such as [[Klingon]][http://www.google.com/intl/xx-klingon/] and [[Leet]][http://www.google.com/intl/xx-hacker/], and [[April Fool's]] jokes [http://www.google.com/googlegulp/] about the company.
+
Their site includes humorous features such as cartoon modifications [http://www.google.com/holidaylogos.html] of their logo for special occasions, the option to display the site in fictional or humorous languages such as [[Klingon language|Klingon]][http://www.google.com/intl/xx-klingon/] and [[Leet]][http://www.google.com/intl/xx-hacker/], and [[April Fool's]] jokes [http://www.google.com/googlegulp/] about the company.
It is conjectured that Google's response to Yahoo will be personalized searches, using the personal data that is gathering from [[Orkut]], [[Gmail]], and [[Froogle]] to give results based on the individual. In fact, there is a [http://labs.google.com/personalized Personalized Google Search] Beta in [http://labs.google.com/ Google Labs], the experimental section of Google.com.
It is conjectured that Google's response to Yahoo will be personalized searches, using the personal data that is gathering from [[Orkut]], [[Gmail]], and [[Froogle]] to give results based on the individual. In fact, there is a [http://labs.google.com/personalized Personalized Google Search] Beta in [http://labs.google.com/ Google Labs], the experimental section of Google.com.
